Description: Egyptian terracotta inkwell. An inkwell with a pointed base, bulging body and flat top, with a low raised rim round the dip-hole. Wheel-made. Orange-brown Nile silt, with abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions, many vesicles left by organic temper.
Curator's comments: Probably locally made at Naukratis. A close parallel was found east of the Merenptah Temple, Memphis, dated c.300 BC, but with an open top (Petrie 1909: pl. xlvi:46; Petrie Museum uc19410). However, this form was already in production in the late period as little models used in various contexts, including funerary. Petrie, W. M. F. 1909. ‘Memphis, vol I’. London.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3673)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (TI.02) (Phase 3)
